story: Schools may remain open to some children despite thevirus-related shutdown.Most pupils are todayhaving their final stint in the classroom for the foreseeable future.Home-learning plans are due to be communicated to parents over the weekend.But today Scottish Borders Council chief executive Tracey Logan has suggested school doors will stay open for certain pupils.She said: "Our intention is that schools will be open from Monday,March , to cater for vulnerable pupils and those whose parents have been identied as key workers."The meaning of key workers is still being considered by officials, said Ms Logan, but guidance is set to be issued today.The definition will be"broadly in line"with that composed by the Scottish government, Ms Logan said.The local authority chief says complex needs facilities will remain openShe added: ldquoPriority will also be given to supporting senior pupils to ensure they are able to complete required SQA course work.ldquoAll of this will be augmented by an alternative education provision based on remote learning."Work is also underway to ensure vulnerable pupils in receipt of free school meals continue to be supported.ldquoAll our early years establishments will be closing and we will be working with private and voluntary providers to ensure they continue to operate and provide much needed support.ldquoMore information will be provided as soon as possible and we would ask parents to monitor our usual communication channels for updates, mainly SBCs website www.scotborders.gov.uk coronavirus and our social media channels.

title: man-went-joyriding-borders-bus-gets-ban
story: A MAN who stole a bus and went joyriding has been banned from driving.Josh Nordon, , of Hawick, took the vehicle from the Borders Buses Depot in Burnfoot Road, Hawick, and was spotted driving it dangerously in Mart Street.He travelled at excessive speed, ignored road signs and drovein the opposite carriageway on the night of March , .Jedburgh Sherf Court was told that Nordons father worked for Borders Buses and that he had taken the bus to "show off" to a friend.He also admitted taking a car without the consent of the owner from Bourtree Place and had no insurance.Nordon pleaded guilty to wasting police time by alleging his neighbour in Hamilton Road, Hawick, was arguing with his we and was in possession of a firearm - a claim that was untrue.Procurator fiscal Fraser Matheson said a "signicant amount of resources" had been allocated to deal with the incident due to the firearms claim.Defence lawyer Ed Hulme said his client had said in his words he had been a "stupid idiot."As an alternative to custody Nordon was given a Community Pay Back Order with a night time home curfew.He was disqualied from driving for  months and fined pound.

title: hunt-master-accused-making-false-statement-application
story: THE master of one of Scotlands leading hunts has been accused of making a  statement in support of a firearms application.David Lee Peters, , is charged with failing to disclose medical information.The offence is alleged to have happened at the Jedforest Hunt Kennels near Bonchester Bridge on April .He pleaded not guilty to the charge under section  of the Firearms Act  and a trial date has been set for March  at Jedburgh Sherf Court.

title: lidl-creates-2-500-four-week-store-jobs-cope-coronavirus
story: Supermarket Lidl will be taking on, workers to start immediately in stores to help cope with the surge in demand due to the coronavirus outbreak.Bosses said the new positions will be four-week contracts, helping to restock shelves and assist staff.They added anyone who has lost their job as a result of businesses shutting down over Covid- should apply, and will pay pound. an hour for staff outside London, or pound. in the capital.The move follows similar announcements from Co-op and Morrisons that they are vastly expanding their workforce to cope with the extra demand of families in self-isolation.Lidl, which has  stores across the country, said: ldquoThe new hires will be responsible for working together to keep the store clean, tidy and the shelves well stocked so that customers can get the products they need. Shts could include mornings, evenings and weekends.Christian Hartnagel, chief executive of Lidl GB, said: ldquoOur store colleagues are doing an incredible job at keeping our shelves stocked, and serving communities during an extremely challenging period.ldquoTemporarily expanding our teams is one way we can help support our colleagues and customers, whilst providing work to those that have had their employment affected by the current situation.Office-based colleagues will also be working from home, and the company will introduce ldquoflexible options including sick pay, holiday pay, advanced holiday pay and mobile working where applicable.

title: schools-stay-open-certain-children-borders
story: Some children will be able to attend school on Mondayand Tuesday, Scottish Borders Council has confirmed.Among nursery and primary-aged children, vulnerable youngsterscan attend ndashas can the childrenof key workers.But the council has said thatit is possible for a child to remain at home, then they should.The local authorityhas defined keyworkersas follows:bull NHS staff engaged in the national response to COVID- bull Health and social care staffbull Emergency servicesbull Staff working in schools and early years provisionsbull Scottish Borders Councilemployees delivering key services directly in response to COVID-.School transport will run as normal,packed lunches will be provided and children can wear their own clothes.Secondary-agedstudents will learn from home, but S students may attend schooltheir key worker parents would not like them to remain at home alone.Full details on the plans can be accessed on the councils website here.

title: cinema-pub-galashiels-ask-help-shutdown
story: The cinema in Galashiels has teamed up with a pub to ask for help during the coronavirus shutdown.The Pavilion, on Market Street,and Bank Streets Salmon Inn are calling on people to buy gt vouchers that can be used when the premises re-open.Cinema manager Andrew Poole said: "Itrsquos vital we are in a strong position and lsquobusiness readyrsquo when the time comes to re-open, and by supporting your local business now by buying gt vouchers or gt cards this can make a massive dference to the survivability of that business."Partner of the Salmon Inn Michelle Douglas said the pub was going through an "extremely dficult time".She said: "Buying a gt voucher will help us to keep operating as a business while the shutdown is in place. And will ensure we are ready to open once the word comes through.Gt cards from the Pavilion can be puchased through its website, while vouchers for the Salmon Inn can be bought through its Facebook page.Mr Poole said: ldquoSmall businesses in Galashiels and the wider Borders are facing down the devil."While closed we have limited or no source of cash over the counter income."We do not have the economy of scale that major retail operators enjoy and every penny counts towards keeping us in business."Mr Poole added: "Michelle and I are appealing for you to make contact with your local business and see what they can offer."

title: borders-buses-suspend-routes-reduce-services
story: MORE than a dozen bus services in the Borders are to be temporarily suspended from tomorrow.And the remainder will operate on a reduced timetable until the coronavirus emergency eases.Borders Buses are still attempting to transport key workers around the region.A spokeswoman for the company told us: "Our team plays a vital role in safely and responsibly transporting key workers living in our communities."Safety is our number one priority and we shall continue to closely monitor the coronavirus outbreak and take guidance from both the Scottish and UK governments."From Monday we will temporarily reduce the level of services being operated."We will also be suspending a number of routes."The routes which will continue to operate at a reduced service are the X, X, ,  and , , , , , , A and B, S , , , , , , B, H and the H.Until further notice, the , B, , ,, ,   , , , , , , B, P, X, Y will be suspended.Further details of the reduced timetables will be available on the Borders Buses website and social media channels.

title: royal-burghs-banksy-leaves-mark-mosaic
story: THEY do things a little dferently in Selkirk - even the graffiti.Over the past few weeks little mosaic masterpieces have been popping up all over the Royal Burgh.The tile-sized designs have been found at the entrances to at least half-a-dozen of the towns historic closes.Local businessman Colin Turnbull said: "Its making folk scratch their heads - in a good way though."The eye-catching mosaics are believed to be in the style of the Warli tribe of the Maharashtra region of India.And it is thought each design could represent the name of the close where it appears.

title: a7-set-april-overnight-closure
story: MOTORISTS are being told to expect an overnight closure from Ashkirk Junction for maintenance work.The roadworks will begin on Friday, April  and will run from pm until am on Saturday, April .Diversions will be in place for the duration of the closure.A spokesperson from Amey, who maintain Scotlands trunk roads, said: "The works will benefit over , vehicles using this section of the A each day, by improving the condition of the carriageway and reducing the need for more extensive maintenance in the future."Southbound traffic will be erted to exit the A at Ladylands, Selkirk, via a left turn onto the A and at St Boswells Crossroads, traffic will turn right to join the A southbound. Traffic will proceed on this route and at Cleekimin Junction, will turn right to join the A."Traffic will continue for  miles towards Hawick and will be instructed to turn right onto Mart Street. At North Bridge Roundabout, traffic will be able to rejoin the A southbound carriageway and ersion will end."Northbound traffic will follow the same ersion route but in the opposite direction."

title: driver-accused-speeding-limit-a68
story: A MOTORIST accused of drink-driving at mph will not face trial at Jedburgh Sherf Court for almost seven months.Scott Harrison, ,from Durham, appeared from custody and denied the speeding offence on the A at Wiselaw Mill near Lauder on Wednesday .He was also accused of being more than double the legal drink-drive limit.He pleaded not guilty to driving with an alcohol breathcount of  microgrammes - the legal limit being .Due to new measures introduced to control the spread of coronavirus and the pressure on court business, a trial date was fixed for October  with an intermediate hearing on September  and Harrison was liberated on bail.

title: thief-broke-kelso-houses-sentenced-deferred
story: A -year-old man who admitted two thefts by housebreaking earlier this month has been remanded in custody for the production of background reports.David Cotton appeared at Selkirk Sherf Court on a videolink live from Saughton Prison in Edinburgh where he admitted the two break-ins at houses in Maxmill Park, Kelso, on Saturday, March .He stole a quantity of electronic items from one house and at another flat he took a television and a DVD player.Sentence was deferred for the production of a Criminal Justice Social Work Report and a Restriction of Liberty Order assessment until April  and Cotton was remanded in custody.

title: new-homes-st-boswells-use-90-per-cent-less-energy
story: THE latest energy-saving houses which are being built across the Borders have been finished in St Boswells.Eildon Housing believes that their new Passivhaus-designed properties will require only  percent of the energy used by conventional households.The revolutionary insulation incorporated into the buildings vastly reduces the energy needs for heating and hot water.Last week the Selkirk-based housing association handed over the keys to the recently finished homes at Springfield Place in St Boswells.And more are on the way at ious developments across the region.Nile Istephan, chief executive of Eildon, said: "More people are set to benefit from the savings as an extra  homes will be built using greener construction methods across the Borders in a pilot that is being run in partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Construction Scotland Innovation Centre and Glasgow School of Art."Construction costs, time to build, as well as feedback from tenants on their experience of living in the new greener homes, will help determine how homes of the future are built and combat fuel poverty."This is all part of Eildonrsquos strategy of delivering inclusive growth across the Borders."

title: stow-volunteers-give-daily-soup
story: AN action group has been set up in Stow to provide help for the elderly and vulnerable during the coronavirus outbreak.With the over-s and anyone with underlying health conditions being urged to self-isolate, collecting medication and going for groceries is proving dficult.Stow Covid- Action Group is offering to provide a delivery service to anyone in the village who needs it.And they are also hoping to provide daily soup deliveries to people in self-isolation.Stow Covid- Action Group is being organised by local businesswoman Jemma Macvie.She told us: "We want to organise a service which will include delivering orders made and paid directly with Stow Post Office, collecting and helping Stow Medical Centre with prescription deliveries, phoning or video calling someone in isolation to keep them company, and collecting parcels or posting mail."Were also looking at setting up a soup group, where people in the community will make home-made nutritional soup and deliver to those in need for a small charge to cover the ingredients."Leaflets are being distributed around Stow to highlight the group.And a Facebook page has also been created.Jemma added: "I have set this up to help the elderly, ill and vulnerable residents of our community."I have been in conversations with other businesses and groups in the village and together we are working as a team."Anyone who is fit and healthy, and not showing any coronavirus symptoms, and would like to volunteer should contact Jemma at JR@eventsandsales

title: feature-ghost-hunting-haunted-melrose-hotel
story: Ghost hunters visited a hotel in Melrose this month to run a spooky night-time tour. Editor Andrew McQuarrie grabbed a torch, pulled on his big-boy trousers and joined the funhellipIt was .pm on a Saturday night and I was trying to communicate with a supernatural beingusing a pair of copper rods.Having done as instructed and asked the tools a simple lsquoYes Norsquo question, I was slightly dismayed to see the rods stubbornly remaining still, the spirit apparently refusing to play ball.Sheila, an employee of UK Ghost Nights, appeared quite perplexed as her eyes darted between me and the rods.ldquoAre you a sceptic  she asked, a faint edge of suspicion laced in her voice.I admitted that I was indeed a sceptic, but one who was more than willing to be converted into a true believer.Happy with this answer, Sheila ushered me into a corner that was, she said, known to be particularly popular with spirits.ldquoAre we in Melrose  I asked the rods, willing them to show even the smallest hint of movement.But after a full minute of tense observation, it was plain to see the equipment would not co-operate.An hour earlier, when the ghost experts were delivering their briefing, they had promised the  paying customers that ldquonothing is fabricated on the tours.The insinuation, it seemed to me, was that this would likely not be a night of high drama and theatrics.Nevertheless, I couldnrsquot help but feel a bit disappointed that my opening bid to converse with the dead had fallen distinctly flat.And over the next four hours, so it would prove, my luck would not change much.Yet, as I wandered the portrait-lined corridors of the George  Abbotsford Hotel, trying to channel my inner Bill Murray, some of the people to whom I spoke offered compelling tales.Few were as gripping as those delivered by Dawn Barrett - owner of the hotel for the last  months - and her cooking team.Among the unusual goings-on noted by Mrs Barrett, for instance, were lights turning on and off on their own, furniture moving around, footsteps at all hours and even the feeling of her hair being brushed.Asked for her views on the supernatural, Mrs Barrett said: ldquoI definitely believe - Irsquove seen and heard too much now.It was Mrs Barrett herself who contacted UK Ghost Nights in the first place, with the aim of getting to the root of what makes the hotel tick.ldquoI want to know why they [spirits] are here. I donrsquot understand how they can put lights on and off. I just want to understand it more, she said.Head chef Kailee Reidie, , spoke of an alarming encounter with a spirit who has come to be known as John, supposedly a grouchy ex-chef.As Kailee turned on the fryer one evening, while she was alone in the kitchen, her hair was pulled back so sharply that she was thrown into the table behind her, banging her head.ldquoAs soon as I turned my back on him [John], thatrsquos when it happened, recalled Kailee, going on to explain her emotions at the time.ldquoI was in shock because I knew he [John] was there, but Irsquom not a big believer in ghostshellip Irsquove never seen John - itrsquos just a feeling.Just a feeling. Well, there was certainly a sense of foreboding in some areas of the building - not least the cellar and the attic.In one of the attic rooms, we indulged in an activity called the lsquohuman pendulumrsquo. This entails three people standing in a row, with the person in the middle acting as the spiritrsquos means of communication.When the spirit is asked a Yes No question, the piggy in the middle is expected to rock forwards for a lsquoYesrsquo and backwards for a lsquoNorsquo - a movement being directed by the answering spirit.One by one, the customers lined up to participate in this creepy experiment, watched by the rest of the room with a mixture of excitement and dread.Time and again, the spiritrsquos presence was well felt. In fact, there turned out to be a number of obliging spirits, each surprisingly keen to answer questions including, lsquoDo you have childrenrsquo  and lsquoAre you happy with us being herersquo As I watched this circus unfold, I was praying Irsquod be able to endure the entire episode as an observer, a witness to the craziness.Not so much because I was scared - although I was a little, I must admit - but more because I knew what would happen.,params: .pushldquoAndrew, would you like to have a shot in the middle What followed was several minutes of embarrassment for everyone.Because of course I didnrsquot move. Not even an inch. And the change in atmosphere was so marked that I genuinely wonderedmy trousers had somehow dropped to my ankles without my noticing.Thankfully, my clothes had remained bound to my body, but any faith I might have had in the ghost-hunting process was sliding away fast.As the tour continued, taking in several other locations promising ldquohigh activity, it became increasingly dficult to muster the energy to stay alert, with the clock ticking into the wee small hours.That said, there was one incident which aroused a certain degree of puzzlement - a maglite which appeared to flash when certain questions were posed.Admittedly, that was a curious development. But still not enough to push me into the camp of believers.The more I dwelt on the nightrsquos events, however, the more I came to realise the deeper signicance of it all.Before the tour, UK Ghost Nights founder Lisa Tedstill had made sure I was aware of the crucial equipment to bring.ldquoAll you need is a torch and a sense of humour, she said, going on to lay her finger on the true essence of the affair.ldquoWe donrsquot guarantee there will be any paranormal activity - anyone who does that is a charlatan.ldquoBut we can guarantee everybody will have a very fun experience.And, indeed, while I may have left the George  Abbotsford that night without a firmer belief in ghosts, I certainly ed home with a smile.

title: council-powers-handed-chief-meetings-scrapped
story: PLANS to hand Scottish Borders Councilchief Tracey Logan delegated control of decision-making are expected to be rubber-stamped this week.It comes hot on the heels of Prime Minister Boris Johnsonrsquos instruction that everyone in the UK should spend most of their time at home in order to counter the coronavirus outbreak.But on Thursday , in an unprecedented move, proposals to temporarily delegate the local authorityrsquos decision-making responsibility to the Chief Executive will be passed.Council meetings in Newtown St Boswells will be cancelled until September , with the exception of vital committee meetings which will be done through video-conferencing.SBC chief legal officer Nuala McKinlay stated: ldquoAs the virus makes a wider impact on public le, Scottish Borders Council must consider how to respond."In taking any decision to protect health by limiting social contact, it must also ensure processes are in place to enable it to continue to make urgent decisions.ldquoIn order to allow decisions to be made, it is proposed that all those decision-making s of council which can lawfully be delegated, be delegated to the chief executive to be made in consultation with members and relevant senior officers.It is also proposed that any committee meetings which do need to take place between now and October will be held via remote video links.Ms McKinlay added: ldquoThe Local Government in Scotland Act  allows a local authority to y that process and conduct a meeting by other ways. It therefore allows members to attend a meeting remotely by use of electronic means.

title: council-chief-asks-workers-keep-running-essential-services
story: The councils chief executive has issued a message to workers running essential services and caring for vulnerable Borders residents.In a statement released today , Tracey Logan urged workers to keep up their efforts.She said: "I am making a plea to those who are involved in the response across the Scottish Borders to continue to undertake your role and help us all ensure the health and wellbeing of our residents remains paramount."An SBC spokesperson said information on council services, including waste collection, can be accessed through this web page.Ms Logans full statement reads: "We continue to work on further details for all our service arrangements."This includes our plans around providing health and social care provision, wider community support as well as things like schools."I am making a plea to those who are involved in the response across the Scottish Borders to continue to undertake your role and help us all ensure the health and wellbeing of our residents remains paramount."That must be the ultimate priority today and in the weeks ahead. "This situation remains extremely challenging and is unlike anything we have ever faced."We are working around the clock to ensure we can continue to make sure people are looked after and have access to help they need."It is vital we all continue to work together to maintain our services for the Scottish Borders and we will make further detailed announcements as soon as possible."

title: images-show-galashiels-first-full-day-virus-lockdown
story: These images capture the first day of Galashiels observing the coronavirus lockdown.Last nightBoris Johnson told UK residents to stay in their homes unless leaving for one of the permitted reasons.And today in Galashiels it seemed that the prime ministers instructions were being respected.Bank Street Gardens was free of pedestrians, while Channel Street was a shopper-free zone.

title: businesses-can-start-applying-coronavirus-support-money
story: Businesses across the Borders can now apply to the Scottish Governmentrsquos Coronavirus Business Support Fund.Scottish Borders Council is delivering the fund in the region on behalf of the Scottish Government.A support fund and one-off small business support grant of pound, is available to ratepayers of businesses located in a non-domestic property which are:middot In receipt of the Small Business Bonus Schemeormiddot In receipt of Rural Relief ormiddot Eligible for SBBS, but in receipt of Nursery Relief or Disabled Relief.This is availablethey were the ratepayer for a premises occupied for that business use on March  .A separate one-off grant of pound, is available to the ratepayers of businesses in the retail, hospitality, leisure or sectors operating in a premises with a rateable value of pound, or up to pound,.The application form is an editable PDF so can be completed electronically. Business owners are being asked to complete all parts of the application form that apply to them in full.SBCrsquos Chief Executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoWe understand this is an extremely dficult and uncertain time for all businesses across the Scottish Borders.ldquoThis is why the Council, which is delivering the Coronavirus Business Support Fund on behalf of the Scottish Government in the Borders, is aiming to make payments within ten working days upon receipt of a fully completed application form.The application form can be accessed here.

title: contactless-payment-limit-increase-45---need-know
story: The limit for in-store card transactions by contactless-enabled cardsis to increase soon.At the beginning of next month, the limit will change from pound to pound.Why is the change happening The move has been name to helpreduce physical contact with keypads on chip and pin machines due to the coronavirus crisis.It is hoped the increased limit will helpin the fight against Covid-.When will the change take place The British Retail Consortiumsaid the move would begin on April , , but warned that implementation in some shops may take longer.What has the British Retail Consortium said about this BRC head of payments policy, Andrew Cregan, said: ldquoThe last contactless limit increase to pound took two years to implement but, given the extraordinary circumstances we face today, this new pound limit will be rolled-out from next week.ldquoSome shops will take longer to make the necessary changes, given the strain theyrsquore under. In the meantime, most customers can continue to make contactless payments for higher amounts using their smart phone.Coronavirus: the facts from the World Health Organisation and the NHSWhat is coronavirus COVID- is a respiratory illness that can affect lungs and airways. It is caused by a virus called coronavirus.What caused coronavirus The outbreak started in Wuhan in China in December  and it is thought that the virus, like others of its kind, has come from animals.How is it spread As this is such a new illness, experts still arenrsquot sure how it is spread. But, similar viruses are spread in cough droplets. Therefore, covering your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing, and disposing of used tissues straight away is advised. Viruses like coronavirus cannot live outside the body for very long.What are the symptoms The NHS states that the symptoms are: a dry cough, high temperature and shortness of breath - but these symptoms do not necessarily mean you have the illness. Look out for flu-like symptoms, such as aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose and a sore throat. Itrsquos important to remember that some people may become infected but wonrsquot develop any symptoms or feel unwell.What precautions can be taken Washing your hands with soap and water thoroughly. The NHS also advises to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleevewhen you cough or sneeze put used tissues in the bin immediately and try to avoid close contact with people who are unwell. Also avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth unless your hands are clean.Government adviceAs of Monday,March , the prime minister has put the UK into lockdown and instructed all citizens to stay at home. People can only leave their homes to exercise once a day, go shopping for food and medication, travel for medical needs or to care for a vulnerable person, and travel to work onlyessential. Police will be able to enforce these restrictions.,params: .pushAll non-essential shops will close with immediate effect, as will playgrounds, places of worship and libraries. Large events or gatherings of more than two people cannot go ahead, including weddings and celebrations. Funerals can only be attended by immediate family. Children of separated parents can go between both parents homes.Anyone with a cough or cold symptoms needs to self-isolate with their entire household for  days.The government has now instructed bars, restaurants, theatres and non-essential businesses to close and will review on a lsquomonth to monthrsquo basis. Schools closed from Friday  March for the foreseeable future, and exams have been cancelled.The over s or anyone who is vulnerable or living with an underlying illness are being asked to be extra careful and stay at home to self-isolate. People with serious underlying health conditions will be contacted and strongly advised to undertake "shielding" for  weeks.For more information on government advice, please check their website.Should I avoid public places You should now avoid public places and any non-essential travel. Travel abroad is also being advised against for the next  days at least, and many European countries have closed their borders.What should I doI feel unwell Donrsquot go to your GP but instead call NHS  or look online at the coronavirus service that can tell youyou need medical help and what to do next.When to call NHS NHS  should be usedyou feel unwell with coronavirus symptoms, have been in a country with a high risk of coronavirus in the last  days oryou have been in close contact with someone with the virus.

title: mot-tests-suspended-6-months-amid-coronavirus-lockdown
story: Drivers have been given a -month MOT holiday to help them stick to the coronavirus quarantine.In the immediate aftermath of Boris Johnsons lockdown announcement, there were mixed messages about whether MOT tests would still be required.But the Department for Transport has now made it clear - no MOT tests will be needed for  months, effective March , to enable people to shop for necessities or continue travellingto work "where this absolutely cannot be done from home".Vehicles must still be kept roadworthy and garages will remain open for essential repairs.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said: ldquoWe must ensure those on the frontline of helping the nation combat COVID are able to do so.ldquoAllowing this temporary exemption from vehicle testing will enable vital services such as deliveries to continue, frontline workers to get to work, and people get essential food and medicine.ldquoSafety is key, which is why garages will remain open for essential repair work.If your MOT is due before March , you will still technically need to have a testyou need to driveit or park it on the street - but the DfT says it is working with police and insurers to "ensure people arent unfairly penalised for things out of their control".Other measures taken by the DfT due to the COVID- pandemic include the suspension of practical driving tests, along with annual testingfor lorries, buses and coaches, for up to  months.

title: prince-charles-tests-positive-coronavirus
story: THE Prince of Wales has tested positive for coronavirus, Clarence House has announced.Charles, , is displaying "mild symptoms" but is in good health as he self isolates at home in Scotland, a spokesman said.The Duchess of Cornwall, , has also been tested but does not have the virus.In a statement, Clarence House said: "The Prince of Wales has tested positive for Coronavirus. He has been displaying mild symptoms but otherwise remains in good health and has been working from home throughout the last few days as usual."In accordance with Government and medical advice, the Prince and the Duchess are now self-isolating at home in Scotland. The tests were carried out by the NHS in Aberdeenshire where they met the criteria required for testing."It is not possible to ascertain from whom the Prince caught the virus owing to the high number of engagements he carried out in his public role during recent weeks."

title: dentists-opticians-cancel-routine-appointments-borders
story: DENTISTS and opticians in the Borders have scrapped routine appointments - and GPs will only see patients when "absolutely necessary".NHS Borders issued information on the latest developments today .Ahealth authority spokesperson said: "All GP practices in the Borders have suspended their usual appointment booking arrangements to help protect patients and staff. Practices and treatment rooms will now provide essential services only to patients who require urgent clinical attention via telephone triaging and, where absolutely necessary, via face to face appointment."You should not attend your GP practice unless advised to do so by your GP following telephone triage. Please only call your GP practice with urgent enquiries."The spokesperson added thatanyone needs urgent care for a minor injury that they cannot treat themselves, they should contact their GP practice or,the practice is closed, they should dial  to reach NHS .Dentists and opticians can be contacted by telephone for urgent or emergency advice only.

title: coronavirus-count-borders-rises-15
story: The number of known coronavirus cases in the Borders has risen to .The latest figures, released today , show the tally has gone up by three on yesterday.But the Borders has the lowest total of positive cases in mainland Scotland.Across the nation, a total of patients who tested positive for coronavirushave died.As of  March, a total of , Scottish tests have concluded. title: uk-coronavirus-home-testing-kits-need-know---plus-available
story: Thousands of home tests for coronavirus are to be delivered to people self isolating ldquowithin days - Public Health Englandhave said.Weve put together all the details onwhat you need to know about the -minute home testing kits for coronavirus - including who can access them.How does the coronavirus home test work The test checksa person has detectable antibodies in their blood, which would mean that they have been exposed to the virus.The kit itself looks similar to a pregnancy test. To use it, you have to prick your finger to produce a drop of blood, which is analysed on the device.The test detects the presence of IGM, an antibody that appears in your body early on in the infection, and IGG, which increases when the body responds to the virus.It takes just  to  minutes to complete the test.The results of some of the tests on order can be read by anyone, but others would need to be interpreted by healthcare professionals.How will the test help fight coronavirus In a previous briefing, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that these types of tests could be a ldquogame changer in regards to the ongoing pandemic.Speaking to the Huffington Post, Professor Trudie Lang, director of the Global Health Network, University of Oxford, said that these types of tests would be ldquotransformational in the fight against the virus.She said: ldquoWe can make sure wersquove got doctors or nurses who can work safely in hospitals. People wouldnt have to isolate unnecessarily at home for  days, because yoursquoll be able to tell very quicklypeople have cleared it or not.Currently, itrsquos only patients who have been admitted to hospital who are being routinely tested for the virus.When will the tests be available Today , Professor Sharon Peacock, director of the national infection service at Public Health Englandtold the Science and Technology Committee that . million of these tests have been purchased, and would be available in the ldquonear future.Before the tests are made available, they will first need to be validated in Oxford, to confirm that they are working as expected - this validation should reporedly happen this week.Once this has happened, they will be made available to test healthcare workers, as well as the general public.Peacock said: ldquoSeveral million tests have been purchased for use. These are brand new products.ldquoWe have to be clear they work as they claimed to do.When askedthey would be made available in days, rather than weeks or months, Peak said: ldquoYes, absolutely.How will they be distributed Online retail giant Amazon has agreed to carry out distribution of the tests, which will also be available to purchase in chemist shops as well, such as Boots.Peacock said: ldquoOnce they have been tested this week and the bulk of tests arrive, they will be distributed into the community.It was also revealed that the UK is not the only country that is ordering these tests.ldquoTests are being ordered across Europe and where and purchased in south-east Asia. title: powers-handed-tracey-logan-emergency-scottish-borders-council-meeting
story: TRACEY Logan has been handed temporary control of Scottish Borders Councildecisions.In an emergency full council meeting, held on March  through video-conferencing, elected members agreed that meetings should be cancelled until September  to "minimise social contact during the coronavirus outbreak".In the meantime, decisions will be made, where possible, by Ms Logan.The proposal was moved for approval by council leader Shona Haslam and seconded byTweeddale East representativeStuart Bell, before being supported by all  members present, according to a council spokesperson.A section of the proposal read: "There is a risk that, should Council and committee meetings continue in their present form, coronavirus will spread wider in the community."Council business, including decision-making, must however continue so that there is least impact on service provision."By allowing greater flexibility in the decision-making processes, the Council can be confident that it will be able to carry out its s in a way that creates least risk to public health."Any meetings which must take place will be conducted using video-conferencing technology.

title: eildons-named-one-uks-best-summer-walks
story: A hike over the Eildons has been named one of the best summer walks in the UK.Travel website Wanderlust has drawn up a list of the seven top routes to tackle in the warmer months.And a traipse up the Eildons, near Melrose, emerged as one of the favourites.In an article published on March , Heather Moat praises the seven-mile walk for its offering of "panoramic vistas".She writes: "Come in late summer when the heather is in full bloom on the slopes, bag the three peaks and explore the abbey town of Melrose on the River Tweed before following St Cuthbertrsquos Way back to your starting point."Among the other locations mentioned in the Wanderlust guide are Anglesey in Wales, Durdle Door in Dorset and Rudyard Lake in Staffordshire.

title: q-megxit-happens-next
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex sparked a major royal crisis by announcing that they wanted to quit as senior royals.Here is a look at the ins and outs of the Megxit troubles.ndash What will happen on March  Itrsquos ldquoMegxit Day, so from midnight on March  Harry and Meghan cease to be senior royals as they walk away from the monarchy. They will stop using their HRH styles.No documents will be signed or laws passed and the decision will not be binding, but it marks a new phase in their le.ndash Will they carry out any more royal duties No. The couple are quitting, not just as senior royals, but as working royals in general.ndash Was this what they wanted Not quite. Harry and Meghan wanted to step down as senior royals but have a dual role, supporting the Queen and earning their own money.ndash But this was unworkable Yes. They effectively could not have their cake and eat it.It was too controversial given their global profiles and would have led to accusations they were cashing in on their royal status.ndash How did the Queen sort out the saga The monarch held a crisis summit at Sandringham with Harry, the Prince of Wales and the Duke of Cambridge ndash and it was announced a few days later there would be no dual role for the Sussexes.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen greets her grandson Harry at the Cha Flower Show ndash Why did Harry and Meghanrsquos plans cause such shock waves Harry and Meghan issued a bombshell statement on January , without warning the Queen and the Prince of Wales and after being told by the monarch to discuss matters with Charles first.ndash Why did they want to step down as senior royals The couple spoke of their struggles dealing with royal le and the intense tabloid interest in a television documentary about their Africa tour.Meghan said: ldquoItrsquos not enough to just survive something, thatrsquos not the point of le. You have got to thrive.Harry has since said he wanted his family to have a ldquomore peaceful le.ndash What were the low points following their wedding Controversies included rows over privacy and use of private jets, a falling out between Harry and William, the launch of legal action and an attack on the press which overshadowed an official royal tour.vw,vw,px, px"Harry and Meghan on their official tour of South Africa ndash Where will they live Harry and Meghan, with their son Archie Mountbatten-Windsor, were renting on Vancouver Island in Canada, but have now moved to the US, setting up home in Los Angeles, Calornia where Meghanrsquos mother Doria Ragland lives.ndash What about Frogmore Cottage Harry and Meghan will keep their Windsor home, start paying commercial rent, and pay back pound. million in taxpayersrsquo money spent on its renovations.vw,vw,px, px"Megxit comes just  months after Harry and Meghan wed ndash What will they be called Initially the palace said they would be Harry, Duke of Sussex and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex.But it was pointed out the titles mirrored those of a orcee ndash the Princess of Wales became Diana, Princess of Wales following the end of her marriage to Charles.They will be the Duke and Duchess of Sussex ndash but without their HRHs.ndash Who had a similar title Wallis Simpson ndash the last American orcee to marry a senior royal, for whom Edward VIII abdicated the throne.vw,vw,px, px"The Duke and Duchess of Windsor Mrs Simpson became the Duchess of Windsor, but was never permitted to be an HRH.ndash Have they been stripped of their HRHs like Diana No. Harry was born a prince and remains so. They will retain their HRHs but will not use them.ndash How will they make money They are predicted to make millions from public speaking, lucrative contracts, book deals ndash or perhaps, for Meghan, ato acting.ndash What have they done already Meghan has narrated a Disneynature film about a family of elephants and their journey across Africa ndash which will air on April  ndash nine months after Harry, while on an official engagement, told a Disney boss his we was available for voiceover work.Disneynaturersquos Elephant, an Original Movie narrated by Meghan, The Duchess of Sussex, starts streaming April , only on #DisneyPlus. pic ArpgkbrjRjmdash Disney+March , A donation was made to a conservation charity, but it is not knownMeghan received a separate fee.Sources say she has no further deals with Disney, whether superhero movies, animated films or otherwise.ndash And Harry Harry, accompanied by Meghan, gave a speech in February at a JP Morgan event in Miami, Florida, and talked about the therapy he had over the death of his mother.Speculation was re he could have received a fee worth hundreds of thousands of pounds.ndash Will they be financially independent Not completely. The Prince of Wales will also continue to offer private financial support to the couple.vw,vw,px, px"The Prince of Wales will support Harry and Meghan This is expected to come from his pound million a year Duchy of Cornwall income.ndash Will they launch their own charitable foundation Yes but they are not calling it a foundation. Harry and Meghan intend to ldquodevelop a new way to effect change with a non-profit organisation, details of which have yet to be unveiled.ndash Will they still be able to use Sussex Royal as their brand No. The Queen and her senior officials have declared they must drop the use of the word ldquoRoyal.vw,vw,px, px"Harry and Meghanrsquos first Sussex Royal Instagram post ndash Are Harry and Meghan happy about this They donrsquot appear to be. Their website states they will not use ldquoRoyal but argues that the monarchy has no jurisdiction over the use of the word ldquoRoyal overseas.ndash What will their new brand name be It is expected to be announced soon. They will have to change their @SussexRoyal Instagram handle. Some options are already taken ndash HM is already a major clothing retailer.ndash Who will pay for their security This is causing controversy. US President Donald Trump has insisted America will not foot the bill.A spokeswoman for the Sussexes said privately-funded security arrangements have been made and the couple will not ask the US government for help.But it is unclear whether the private security arrangements are in addition to, or instead of, the couplersquos politan Police protection officers, and whether any police protection officers being used will continue to be paid for by UK taxpayers.It is also unclear who is paying for the private arrangements ndash whether it is the Sussexes, the Queen or the Prince of Wales.vw,vw,px, px"The Duchess of Sussex is escorted through a market in Suva, Fiji, during an official tour Neither Buckingham Palace nor the Home Office will confirm details, but the total security bill is estimated to be as much as pound million a year.Harry and Meghan have already left Canada, where the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said it would stop providing protection after Megxit.ndash What have Harry and Meghan said previously Their website claims it is agreed they ldquorequire effective security to protect them because Harry was ldquoborn into the royal family and because Meghan has her ldquoown independent profile.ndash What about their patronages They will keep their royal patronages as private patronages and associations.But Harryrsquos military appointments will be put on hold for the next  months.ndash What about their Commonwealth roles Harry is quitting his role as Commonwealth Youth Ambassador.But he will remain president of the Queenrsquos Commonwealth Trust, and Meghan will still be the Trustrsquos vice-president.vw,vw,px, px"Harry, Meghan and Archie ndash Where will Archie go to school As Archie will be spending most of his time in North America, it it is likely he will not have a British education, but nothing has been confirmed.ndash What about Meghanrsquos citizenship At the time of their engagement, it was announced that Meghan would be applying for British citizenship.It is not known what stage the process was at or what will happen now.ndash Will they been seen again in the UK Unlikely for a while with the UK in lockdown.Harry was due at the London Marathon in April in a non-royal capacity, but the race has been postponed until October, and the Trooping the Colour celebrations of the Queenrsquos official birthday in June, when Harry and Meghan could have joined the royals, will not happen in its traditional form.vw,vw,px, px"The royals at Buckingham Palace ndash Is this end of Harry and Meghanrsquos royal roles forever Possibly not. The situation will be reviewed by the monarchy in  monthsrsquo time, leaving the door open in case of a change of heart.The Queen has told Harry the couple are much loved by the royals and would be welcomed backthey wanted to be working royals in the future.ndash Arenrsquot there more pressing issues Exactly. The Megxit saga began before the UK was affected by the coronavirus outbreak.Now the country is in the midst of unprecedented peacetime restrictions and dealing with the biggest public health crisis in a generation, as the world battles the pandemic.Harryrsquos father the Prince of Wales has tested positive for the Covid- illness and the -year-old Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh, , are staying at Windsor Castle for their safety.ndash But is Harry still in the line of succession Yes, he remains sixth in line and Archie is seventh in line..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: QA: What is Megxit all about and what happens next

title: coronavirus-classes-queen-margaret-university-postponed-next-week
story: The university, near Musselburgh, outlined their stance yesterdayand vowed to keep students and staff updated of any future developments.Dr Richard Butt, deputy principal, said: "Queen Margaret University is continuing to monitor closely and follow healthcare and Government advice from Health Protection Scotland."Our campus and halls of residence remain open. We will comply with advice from Health Protection Scotland and the Scottish Government and take any necessary stepswe are advised to do so in the future."The guidance on the website will be updated,required, by pm each day."Learning and teaching will move entirely online by next Monday .Dr Butt added: "We will be moving to delivering teaching online."Reduced face-to-face teaching will begin from Monday , and no face-to face teaching will take place from March  until further notice."If there are any changes to your classes in the week beginning March , information will be published on the Hub."Academic staff will decide how best to conduct teaching and learning activities, using a range of resources to best support students."Meanwhile, all undergraduate and taught postgraduate exams and assessments scheduled for next Monday, including those for the Semester  exam period , and reassessments scheduled for the end of July, will be delivered online or by other methods of alternate assessment.Assessment type will be guided by academic discipline and academic staff expertise.Students will be notied as early as possible about what online assessments mean in practice.Inidual Learning Plan Adjustments will also continue.Students wishing tohome can do so.Dr Butt added: "We understand that some students, particularly those from overseas, may be anxious and you may be considering ing home."If you do decide tohome, you will not be penalised for doing so."Whilst we are changing our mode of learning and teaching and taking measures to be responsive to an evolving situation, QMUrsquos campus will remain open."We have had no indication from Health Protection Scotland or the Scottish Government that we should close, and buildings, services and facilities will run as usual.Staff and students can be on campus and our library, specialist facilities, student services, refectory, the halls of residences and Studentsrsquo Union are also open."We will title: coronavirus-musselburgh-racecourse-hold-meetings-behind-closed-doors
story: This weekrsquos Racing Post Go North race day will be open only to racing connections and will be in line with the Scottish Government recommendation that no events of more than  people should be held in light of the coronavirusoutbreak.Those attending will be asked to sign a self-declaration form that they do not have a temperature or symptoms associated with coronavirus. Anyone who has pre-booked tickets for either March race day will receive a full refund.Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said: "Behind closed doors racing will comply with the guidelines set out by the Scottish Government and a meeting of less than  people, which includes participants, connections and staff, will not add any additional stress to emergency services."The racing industry, like many other sectors, is facing unprecedented challenges and is fighting for its future. We are keen to do whatever we can to support jobs and to mitigate loss of income, and holding meetings behind closed doors seems a sensible approach."Racingrsquos governing body the British Horseracing Authorityearlier announced all racing in Scotland, England and Wales would take place without spectators and with attendance limits until March .Nick Rust, chief executive of the BHA, said: "Racecourses and racing yards are embedded in their local communities and we are acutely aware of our responsibilities to protect public health."The restrictions we are putting in place to close racing to spectators and limit attendees will reduce demand on public services. We also have a range of measures in place designed in response to the Governmentrsquos guidance on public health and we will continue to update these as appropriate."Musselburgh will review how racing may proceed for its popular Betway Easter Saturday Race Day on April  as the situation develops and will continue to follow all Government and NHS advice on best practice on containing the virus.Regular updates on the racecourse website and social media channels,will advise racegoers, owners and trainers on any material changes to scheduled race meetings.For more information, visit musselburgh-racecourse

good as their word at the time of our participation in the masterplan consultations ndash to formally adopt the masterplan so that a template exists for the site which clearly reflects the hopes, dreams and aspirations of our communities. Where green space and environment are respected, enhanced and sit alongside industry and energy at Cockenzie, as has been the case for decades and generations.ldquoHad ELC formally adopted the masterplan, Inch Cape would not be located on the coastal frontage of the site, but in Zone , the Energy Quarter, and our communities would not have had the ision and angst caused by the Skyrora proposal to test rocket engines in the midst of communities.ldquoThis week, we read that a large area of land in the Scottish Borders has been passed to the community at a cost to them of pound so that their aspirations for the future can be achieved.ldquoWe ask that ELC either formally adopt the Cockenzie Masterplan or follow that lead and gt the site to the communities.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe recognise the importance of the sitersquos future and remain committed to working with and updating local stakeholders.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site has signicant potential for economic development and employment opportunities. The masterplan report ndash which reflects this and set out options for a mixed-use site ndash continues to be an important visionary document.ldquoSince its publication, Inch Cape Offshore Limitedhas received planning permission from Scottish Ministers to build onshore transmission works on part of the site.ldquoAlso, the National Planning Framework continues to include Cockenzie as a site of signicance for thermal energy generation.ldquoIt remains the case that we need to understand whether there are any implications for the site arising from the next National Planning Framework, as well as from potential future planning policy considerations and further technical work.ldquoWe see the masterplan report as one of a number of important considerations that will inform the councilrsquos input to the development plan process. The council is also determined that further technical work was required on the viability of port-related development.ldquoUnderstanding the full implications of all of this is key before the future of the whole site can be determined.The plan was originally drawn up by Peter Brett Associates, appointed by East Lothian Council.The petition can be viewed at change.org p east-lothian-council-petitioning-east-lothian-council-to-formally-adopt-the-cockenzie-masterplan

title: coronavirus-churches-urged-stop-services-prevent-spread-virus
story: A spokesperson for the Church of Scotland said on Tuesday: ldquoThe Scottish Governmentnow advisesthat people should minimise social contact by avoiding crowded areas and large gatherings, including religious congregations, and smaller gatherings.ldquoThe Church of Scotland now asks, in the strongest terms, that all gatherings for worship should cease until further notice.ldquoOther Scottish churches are taking similar actions."This obviously includes Easter services. Some Presbyteries have already instructed this action. This will include, but not be restricted to: housegroups, meetings for youth work, and church cafes.ldquoIt will still be possible for an inidual to offer a livestream of a sermon and prayers.ldquoChurch buildings can be kept open as a place for people to come and pray.Notices should be clearly displayedasking that visitors observe robust hand hygiene, including washing their hands on entry to the church.On weddings and funerals, the Church said that ldquosensitive conversations will need to take place between those affected.The Rev Alison McDonald, from St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Haddington, sent a message to her congregation after the Church of Scotland called for services to be cancelled.She said weekly readings, prayers and reflections would be posted online and plans are being consideredto open the church building for ldquopersonal prayer as the coronavirus crisis continues.The Scottish Episcopal Churchhas also asked its clergy to cease church services.The Most Rev Dr Mark Strange, Primus of the SEC, said: ldquoThis is a dficult time for many people some are fearful for themselves or their relatives, while others want to know how to help stem the spread of the virus.ldquoOur guidance is given not just to address medical concerns but also with pastoral concern being uppermost in our hearts and minds, particularly the care of the vulnerable in our congregations and communities.Church buildings will be allowed to stay open for private prayer. The church will also deliver a video service of the Eucharist every Sunday through its website for those wanting to worship at home.The Catholic Church has cancelled public Masses across Scotland from Thursday and they will not take place until further notice.Masses will still be said in private in churches but not in front of parishioners live streaming will be in place and available where possible.Catholic churches themselves will not be closed completely to allow time for private prayer.

title: weightlifting-headteacher-earns-podium-position-international-event
story: Lynda Banks represented Great Britain at the European Masters Classic Powerlting Championships in France last Monday .The Cockenzie Primary School headteacher lted a whopping  kilogrammes across the three events in the age -,  kilogrammes category, to come home with two bronze medals from the competition in Albi, near Toulouse.Ms Banksrsquo powerlting prowess came about ldquoby pure chance.She had started training at a gym in Inverness when she was , with a view to being strong enough to complete a chin-up.That was successfully achieved and a love of deadlting followed, with the -year-oldrsquos first competition in Dumfries in .Within  months, she had a gold medal for deadlts as part of the British team.Ms Banks swapped Hilton Primary School in Inverness for East Lothian in October last year, the new head replacing Jacqui MacKinnon, who moved on to North Berwickrsquos Law Primary School.The headteacherrsquos positive mental attitude influences her approach to school leadership, and she has shared with schoolchildren in assembly her experiences competing.The Edinburgh resident said: ldquoOne of our school values is positivity.ldquoWhen I competed at the World Championships in Texas I pulled kg, which I hadnrsquot done before, and took overall third place in the world.ldquoHaving a positive attitude is so important.ldquoWe work to foster a sense of school achievement, with a wall where pupils and staff are encouraged to share a wide range of their achievements such as chanter, ing, rock climbing, so we can all celebrate them.The children also enjoy seeing her collection of medals, which she keeps in her office.Five days after making the move to Cockenzie Primary School and nursery, which is home to  pupils, Ms Banks was competing in the British Championships, retaining her title in her age and weight category for the fth successive year, and achieving three personal bests: squat .kg, bench press .kg and total kg, having deadlted kg, too.It was this performance that led to an invitation to take part in Team GB in Albi.The headteacher primarily trains in Edinburgh, although she has started attending Meadowmill Sports Centre, to help fit her training around her busy school schedule.She also works with a nutritionist and said: ldquoI want to be as strong as I can to compete and stay at a healthy weight.ldquoI eat healthily ndash I eat a lot of chicken, rice and porridge and drink plenty of water.ldquoHowever, I can still have cakeI want to!

title: tims-tales-monkey-delivery
story: ldquoWRITE something uplting or funny, my we Kate told me this morning. Shersquos right, of course. We need such stories just now.My response was: ldquoYes, we all need to make our own version of Stone Soup.My youngest daughter overheard me. ldquoYuck, I donrsquot want that, I want porridge for breakfast like usual, she said.I reassured her and reminded her of the story. Itrsquos an old tale Irsquove shared in these pages before. It has many versions and I base the story in a land when there is a famine and people have very little food on which to survive, and so understandably people keep what little they have for their own use.But then a wise traveller fills his pot with water and begins to boil it over a fire. Then he adds a stone. People get curious and ask: ldquoWhat are you making  The traveller replies: ldquoStone soup.ldquoStone soup  Never heard of that.ldquoOh, itrsquos delicious and very filling.ldquoCould I try some ldquoOf course, but it would taste betteryou had something to add to it, says the traveller.And so as the story unfolds, each person adds a little to the pot, which means in the end the soup really is delicious and filling, and there is enough for all, because everyone has shared the little they have.But before they eat, the traveller does one last thing ndash takes out the stone!My daughter remembered the story and was reassured stone soup wasnrsquot on the breakfast menu. But I think the storyrsquos meaning has deeper signicance than just the sharing of food. Itrsquos also about the sharing of ourselves, and how adding a little bit of who we are can transform the pot of community.In the midst of all the fear and panic around us just now, this is what is happening. People are helping out, checking on neighbours and thinking how their own behaviour can affect others who are more vulnerable.And in all this, our mental wellbeing is as important as our physical health. Irsquom reminded of something my motherrsquos partner once told me. His name was Harry. He was originally from Holland and in his childhood he lived through the horric Dutch famine of -.He said: ldquoWe survived on rotten potato soup, tulip bulbs and a joke a day. Sometimes the jokes were as rotten as the potatoes but just as important!We need to smile, laugh and feel connected, especially in dficult times. We can all begin our own metaphorical stone soup and invite others to contribute and share.For example, many of my fellow storytellers are arranging online storytelling sessions. I will be telling stories online for the schools I currently work with and Irsquom happy to do likewise for any other organisation or group ndash once my six-year-old has taught me how the technology works!There are local musicians playing online gigs, people sharing recipes, visiting older family members outside their windows, writing letters and telephoning people for a chat the list goes on. One idea can lead to another, and soon a new community pot is made!Every contribution, no matter how seemingly small, can make a big dference to that pot. And in so doing, it will challenge that sense of despair and powerlessness that so many of us feel right now.So the question should be: Whatrsquos your thing  How can you safely share it  Whatrsquos your amusing or uplting story or your talent  Think about it and letrsquos share, for others, as well as ourselves.And so in the spirit of this, here is my wee contribution for this week itrsquos a funny wee tale passed onto me, so I claim no credit or originality for it. It was told to me by an Irish friend, but Irsquove adapted it slightly.There was this van driver called George who got a job delivering monkeys to the zoo. Unfortunately, his van broke down and while waiting for the mechanic the monkeys began to get restless.Then another van driver called Archie pulled up and askedhe could help.ldquoIrsquom late for my delivery. If I give you pound, will you take these monkeys to the zoo  asked George.ldquoSure, said Archie.So Archie took the monkeys away in his van.George waited for the mechanic and finally his van was repaired. He then set off for the zoo to make sure the monkeys were delivered successfully.But to his surprise, he saw Archie walking along the street with the monkeys!George called out to him: ldquoWhat are you doing  I gave you pound to take the monkeys to the zoo!Archie called back: ldquoI did, but we got a group discount, I have some money left, so now Irsquom taking them to the cinema!

title: coronavirus-residents-urged-keep-helping-east-lothian-foodbank
story: The foodbank, based in Tranent, provides food parcels to vulnerable members of the community.Candace Higgins, foodbank director, said the situation was changing ldquohour by hour, adding: ldquoWe are still operating as normal but certain protocols have been put in place when delivering food parcels.Volunteers making deliveries are now simply knocking on doors or ringing bells, rather than waiting for doors to be opened to them. The parcels can then be left in safe places, while, at the charityrsquos headquarters on Civic Square, ldquostringent cleanliness and health and safety rules are in place.Candace praised the local community for their continued support in making donations to the group.She said: ldquoWe are really benefiting from having such a fantastic community. Donations have gone up rather than down.However, she also issued a call for people to stop panic or bulk buying.She added: ldquoWe are running low on chopped tomatoes, long-le fruit juice, instant mash potato and tinned potatoes. In terms of household items, it would be the same things as everyone  is running low on ndash kitchen roll, toilet roll and baby wipes.The foodbank is staffed by volunteers and Candace said they anticipated a number of volunteers who are over the age of  would have to remain in their homes over the coming weeks, with a reduced schedule of deliveries. Instead, moves could be made to change the model to a pantry and larder model.The foodbank was visited at the end of last week by the countyrsquos MP, Kenny MacAskill, who met with  volunteers.He said: ldquoThe foodbank is a treasure, but the circumstances that have made these projects so important are the result of bad choices by successive Governments.ldquoItrsquos especially important now with the coronavirus pandemic that we continue to support our local foodbank to make sure those in crisis are able to have at least the comfort of a hot meal.

title: coronavirus-dunbar-civic-week-postponed
story: Dunbarrsquos Civic Week was due to take place from June  to  but the townrsquos community councillors have taken the tough decision to cancel the annual celebration amid fears surrounding coronavirus.George Robertson, chairman of the Civic Week planning committee, spoke to the Courier on Thursday, with the decision officially taken to cancel the event just days later.He said: ldquoThere are discussions taking place and it is very likely to be cancelled.ldquoThat is my recommendation to the community council and I am awaiting them to come back to me.Traditionally, Civic Week, which started in , features dozens of events, ranging from football tournaments to a cycle ride.The townrsquos leboat station opens its doors to visitors and live music is performed at The Battery, at the townrsquos harbour.Central to the event is the crowning of Dunbarrsquos Civic Week Queen, who is a randomly chosen female P pupil from the town.Mr Robertson said there were concerns that coronavirus would decimate the programme, which is already in the process of being drawn up.He said: ldquoYou cannot have a fun day or a parade with  people.ldquoA lot of people are going to be in lockdown.ldquoIt is a real blow and it could not have come at a worse time [the event was due to celebrate  years] but in the grand scheme of things, cancelling Dunbar Civic Week, like Wimbledon and Glastonbury, does not amount to a whole lot of grievance.ldquoI was quite anxious we made a decision.ldquoWe were discussing this before the school closure came about and we were due to have a draw on March  for the Royal Court.Mr Robertson, who is also a member of the townrsquos community council, said ldquoa lot of preparation had already gone into the event and thanked the work of volunteers Eileen Moore and Sanchita Patjoshi in pulling everything together.It remains to be seenthe event will be rescheduled for later in the year or simply resume in the summer of .Mr Robertson noted that attempting to hold the event later in the year created a number of other potential issues.No one knows when everyday events couldto normal in the wake of COVID-, while the children who are currently in P would have moved on to Dunbar Grammar School by the time the event could be held.This yearrsquos event was also due to mark the th anniversary of the granting of the Royal Charter to Dunbar.The Royal Charter was granted to Dunbar by King David the Secondin .This came about because Berwick-upon-Tweed was then in English hands and the lucrative revenues from the export of border wool was lost to the Scottish crown.The granting of a Royal Charter to Dunbar meant that this trade could now go via Dunbar and the port of Belhaven, and revenues revert to Scotland.The th anniversary was celebrated in grand style in  with the very first Dunbar Civic Week, and Civic Week has continued annually ever since.

title: alex-salmond-cleared-east-lothian-mp-says-resignations-required
story: Mr Salmond was on trial on  charges, which included charges of attempted rape and sexual assault.The jury retired to deliberate its verdict on Friday afternoon after a two-week trial but came to its decision today.The -year-old was found not guilty of  charges and not proven for another.In a post on Twitter, East Lothians MP Kenny MacAskill, a known ally of Mr Salmond, said he was ldquodelighted for the former First Minister, adding: ldquoSome resignations now required".

title: coronavirus-scotland-essentially-already-lockdown-businesses-told-close
story: Nicola Sturgeon also indicated that Scotland is essentiallyalready in ldquolockdown, but without it being enforced.She warned that people should remain at home ldquounless itrsquos absolutely essential to go out ndash while Scotlandrsquos chief medical officer, Catherine Calderwood, said that people can go out and exercise once a day but ldquoonly in small family groups.Ms Sturgeon said that the advice issued is ldquorules that we are expecting people to comply with and that businesses that cannot operate remotely should ldquoconsider closing or hibernating.She added: ldquoFor everyone, you must stay at home unless it is absolutely essential to go out. That includes working from home wherever possible.ldquoStay away from crowded places, even out of doors. When there are other people around, stay two metres distance from them.ldquoThat advice is for everyone but it is especially vitalyou are over , eligible for the flu vaccine or pregnant. At all times, follow the advice on washing your hands, using tissues and touching your face.Ms Sturgeon pleaded with businesses that have not yet closed their doors to the public.She said: ldquoIf you are not providing essential items like food and medicines, then please also close now.ldquoThere are still too many people across our country who are being expected to or are expecting to go to work as normal. That presents a serious and unnecessary risk of spreading the virus.Ms Sturgeon added that building sites and hair salons should also close to help in the efforts to suppress the coronavirus pandemic.She added: ldquoI know this is a dficult situation for businesses and I know dficult judgements are having to be made.ldquoI have therefore asked for additional guidance to be drawn up urgently by government for businesses that will make clear exactly what we are expecting of them and how they can make theright judgements on what is essential and whatis not essential.ldquoWe are pushing for and are very hopeful of seeing very seen, further measures to support freelancers, the self-employed and contract workers.ldquoIt should enable businesses to do the right thing for themselves and for their workers.Dr Calderwood said that it was important that people couldleeavetheir homes to exercise once a day for mental and physical wellbeing, but urged people to do it in small family groups to stop the spread of coronavirus.She said: ldquoPeople should go out once a day to exercise but donrsquot do it except in small family groups.ldquoWe are going to have to adapt to le in this new world. We are really in this for the marathon, not a sprint.The First Minister also indicated that Scotland and wider UK is essentially already in ldquolockdown as has been described in Italy and other countries ndash albeit without the enforcement.She said: ldquoIt is very possible that in the days to come, we will see more stringent measures be applied.ldquoIf we take a step back from the word lsquolockdownrsquo, and think about what all the components of that would be - asking people to stay at home and not go to work unless it isvitally essential, asking people not to go shopping unless itrsquos for food and medicine, asking people to keep their distance, not gather in crowds of people.ldquoThatrsquos essentially the elements of what you are seeing in other countries where it has been described as lockdown."I guess the missing bit that we may have to move tothe advice tells us itrsquos necessary, iswhether that is beingissued in a way of advice, although Irsquom being very clear we want people to treat it as rules, or whether there is more enforcement on that. I canrsquot rule that out.She added: ldquoAs First Minister, I will not hesitate to do what is necessary here. Irsquom not ruling anything out.ldquoWhat Irsquom being crystal clear on is that the public donrsquot have to wait for lockdowns or enforcement to do the right things.ldquoItrsquos within the ability of each and every one of us as citizens to do the right things now. Donrsquot wait for somebody to tell you - please do it.

title: coronavirus-east-lothians-coastal-car-parks-closed
story: Childrens play areas in the county have also been closed.East Lothian Council said the decision, which takes effect immediately,was taken due to "the escalating challenges posed by the coronavirus outbreak, the need to ensure appropriate social distancing between iniduals and to reduce the risk of cross-infection from contact surfaces".Monica Patterson, chief executive of East Lothian Council, said: ldquoFrom the outset of the coronavirus outbreak, we have been clear about the need to follow national health and government advice.ldquoAlthough we appreciate that the coastal car parks are popular with those who enjoy our fantastic local beaches ndash particularly during good weather ndash there are concerns about this presenting dficulty for people following social distancing advice at busy times."Itrsquos essential that people avoid gatherings at this time and keep two metres away from other people."Advice against non-essential travel is also in place.ldquoDue to the risk of cross-infection from contact surfaces, we have also reluctantly made the decision to temporarily close the councilrsquos childrenrsquos play areas. This relates specically to areas with play equipment rather than larger parks open spaces which have play areas within them.ldquoWhile we appreciate people will be disappointed, we believe these decisions are in the best interests of everyonersquos health and wellbeing as we respond to the unprecedented challenges presented by this outbreak.The closurealso appliesto the toilet and showering facilities at the car parks.The council is also urging people not to travel to access open space and coastal areas outwith the town or village they reside in, as this could speed up the spread of the virus area to area.The council stated: "Social distancing is key. Everyone should avoid congregating in large groups and stay at least two metres apart from others at all times."We would urge young people and their parents carers to be conscious of this."We would also remind residents that enjoyleisure facilities throughout East Lothian are currently closed ndash from today this will include all G pitches that are fenced off."Images of packed car parks with ice cream vans open for business had appeared across social media at the weekend, with one tractor driver sharing a video of themselves driving up a lane leading to one car park, which was lined with cars parked nose to tail.The video , which was shot at Tyninghame beach, between North Berwick and Dunbar, shows a queue of cars trying to park as others line both sides of the narrow lane after the -space car park filled up."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Busy Tyninghame beach","description": "The lane leading to the Tyninghame beach car park was busy with cars at the weekend.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media GygNAcN poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests GygNAcN.mu","embedUrl":
